page.title: 17LEEDS - LIVERPOOL CANAL
page.content: This was begun in 1770 and finished in 1816. It is 127 miles long, the longest single canal in Britain. This is probably one of the most attractive stretches of the canal passing through open countryside.The canal reaches its summit of 150 metres above sea level just south of our block and gets water from streams and reservoirs in the area (see{WHITEMOOR RESERVOIR}). It passes under Wanless Bridge, an old stone bridge carrying a narrow country lane, leading from Colne to Blacko. The canal then enters the {MILE TUNNEL - actually 1640 yards long. The tunnel has been repaired and new air shafts constructed during the last few years. In 1912, a cow became famous when it fell into the canal and swam through the tunnel.It was rescued at{FOULRIDGE and revived.Leisure craft are a common sight on this stretch of the canal.
